'''Contract cheating''' is a form of [[academic dishonesty]] in which [[student]]s get others to complete their [[coursework]] for them by putting it out to [[call for bids|tender]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2008/may/06/highereducation.students | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Jessica | last=Shepherd | title=The rise of 'contract cheating' at universities | date=2008-05-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/5071886.stm|title=Student cheats contract out work|author=|publisher=BBC/bbc.com|date=2006-06-12|accessdate=2006-06-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/06/13/ncheat13.xml&sSheet=/news/2006/06/13/ixuknews.html/ |title=Cheating students put assignments out to tender on the internet|first=Liz|last=Lightfoot|publisher=Telegraph/telegraph.co.uk|date=2006-06-13|accessdate=2006-06-14|location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/news/news.html?in_article_id=391085&in_page_id=1770|title=The cybercheats making a small fortune|author=|publisher=Daily Mail/dailymail.co.uk|date=2006-06-17|accessdate=2007-11-05|location=London}}</ref>
The term was coined in a 2006 study<ref name="Eliminating">{{cite journal|citeseerx = 10.1.1.120.5440|title=Eliminating the successor to plagiarism? Identifying the usage of contract cheating sites|first1=Robert|last1=Clarke |first2=Thomas|last2=Lancaster|date=2006-06-19|accessdate=<!-- 2007-05-23 -->}}</ref> by Thomas Lancaster<ref>[http://www.bcu.ac.uk/computing/staff-tl.html Thomas Lancaster bio] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091206154603/http://www.bcu.ac.uk/computing/staff-tl.html |date=2009-12-06 }}</ref> and Robert Clarke<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.linkedin.com/pub/robert-clarke/16/12a/967 |title=Robert Clarke bio |publisher=Linkedin.com |date= |accessdate=2013-07-21}}</ref> at [[Birmingham City University|the University of Central England in Birmingham]] (now known as ''Birmingham City University'').
==Extent==
The first published material detailing the extent of contract cheating is a study by Robert Clarke and Thomas Lancaster.<ref name="Eliminating" /> The study presented three main findings:
#Over 12 percent of postings on a popular website for outsourcing computer contract work are actually bid requests from students looking to attempt contract cheating. #Contract cheaters posted an average of 4–7 requests, suggesting that habitual use is made of such services by these students. #A smaller number of users have posted over 50 bid requests, including examples from multiple institutions. This suggests that these are agencies subcontracting work, not students who are directly making use of the services.
Whereas the quality of solutions to assignments sold by [[essay mill]] has been questioned, a study by Jenkins and Helmore showed that work obtained through the use of an [[Online auction|auction site]] was of sufficient quality to gain good marks and remain undetected by the module [[tutor]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ics.heacademy.ac.uk/Events/HEADublin2006_V2/papers/Tony%20Jenkins%2023.pdf |format=PDF|title=T. Jenkins and S. Helmore "Coursework for cash: the threat from on-line plagiarism", in Proceedings of 7th Annual Conference for Information and Computer Science, Dublin. Higher Education Academy pp121-126 (August 2006)}}</ref>
A more recent study examined over 900 examples of contract cheating by students studying computing subjects. The published results categorise the assignment types (e.g. Programming, Database, Web Design) and are analysed by country. One new concern identified by this study was the number of major projects (both final year undergraduate and postgraduate) being posted onto auction sites.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ics.heacademy.ac.uk/events/8th-annual-conf/Papers/Thomas%20Lancaster%20final.pdf|title=Assessing Contract Cheating Through Auction Sites – A Computing Perspective|first1=Robert|last1=Clarke |first2=Thomas|last2=Lancaster|date=2007-08-30|accessdate=2007-09-13 |format=PDF}}</ref>
From a study of 4,000 suspected cases of "contract cheating" some interesting patterns of behaviour have been observed. A summary was presented at the HEA Workshop on Contract Cheating (March 2008).<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.ics.heacademy.ac.uk/events/presentations/682_Private%20Life%20Annotated.pdf|title=The Private Life of an Assignment|first1=Robert|last1=Clarke |first2=Thomas|last2=Lancaster|date=2008-03-07|accessdate=2011-01-09 |format=PDF}}</ref>
At the Aske conference held in June 2009 a paper detailing a "multi-faceted" approach to dealing with the problem of "contract cheating" was presented.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.brookes.ac.uk/aske/documents/Plagiarism09_LancasterClarke.pdf|format=PDF|title=Contract Cheating in UK Higher Education: promoting a proactive approach|first1=Robert|last1=Clarke |first2=Thomas|last2=Lancaster|date=2009-06-04|accessdate=2011-01-09}}</ref>
A paper presented at the STEM conference (April 2012) was a study of over 600 assignments in subject areas ranging from "Anthropology to Theology".<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.heacademy.ac.uk/assets/documents/stem-conference/Computing%201/Thomas_Lancaster_Robert_Clarke.pdf|title=Dealing with contract cheating: a question of attribution|first1=Robert|last1=Clarke |first2=Thomas|last2=Lancaster|date=2012-04-18|accessdate=2012-05-03 |format=PDF}}</ref>
The Commercial Aspects of Contract Cheating are examined in a paper given at ITiCSE '13. This paper analyses the monetary value of contract cheating to the different parties who play a role in the contract cheating process. The main analysis is based on a corpus consisting of 14,438 identified attempts to cheat. The corpus was collected between March 2005 and July 2012.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=2462497|title=Commercial aspects of contract cheating|first1=Robert|last1=Clarke |first2=Thomas|last2=Lancaster|date=2013-07-01|accessdate=2013-08-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.slideshare.net/ThomasLancaster/commercial-aspects-of-contract-cheating-iticse-2013|title=Commercial aspects of contract cheating (Slides)|first1=Robert|last1=Clarke |first2=Thomas|last2=Lancaster|date=2013-07-01|accessdate=2013-08-21 }}</ref>
In a 2017 meta-analysis of 5 studies, 3.5% of a total of 1378 students reported buying assignments to submit as their own. Of the students who reported engaging in contract cheating, more than 60% admitted doing so more than once.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Curtis|first=Guy J.|last2=Clare|first2=Joseph|date=2017-04-20|title=How Prevalent is Contract Cheating and to What Extent are Students Repeat Offenders?|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10805-017-9278-x|journal=Journal of Academic Ethics|language=en|pages=1–10|doi=10.1007/s10805-017-9278-x|issn=1570-1727}}</ref>
==Prevention== The assignments prepared by essay-writing companies and other paid third-parties are supposedly 'original', meaning that they are likely to evade detection by software packages such as Turnitin. Assessment design strategies may limit the possibility that students can use contract cheating services, although a 2014 publication in Educational Studies showed that reducing the time that students have to prepare their assessments is unlikely to deter contract cheating, and that there appeared to be significant spare capacity in the contract cheating market.<ref>Wallace, M.J. and Newton P.M. 2014. [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/03055698.2014.889597#.VDj7k1fbGw0 Turnaround time and market capacity in contract cheating]. Educational Studies. 40(2) 233-236.</ref>
== Detection == In July 2007 a paper proposed a systematic six-stage process that tutors can use to detect students who are contract cheating.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/freeabs_all.jsp?arnumber=4365466|title=Establishing a Systematic Six-Stage Process for Detecting Contract Cheating|last2=Lancaster|first2=Thomas|date=2007-07-26|website=|first1=Robert|last1=Clarke|accessdate=2011-01-09}}</ref> Contract cheating sites often claim this form of cheating is undetectable,<ref name="Lines 889–914">{{Cite journal|last=Lines|first=Lisa|date=2016-11-16|title=Ghostwriters guaranteeing grades? The quality of online ghostwriting services available to tertiary students in Australia|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/13562517.2016.1198759|journal=Teaching in Higher Education|volume=21|issue=8|pages=889–914|doi=10.1080/13562517.2016.1198759|issn=1356-2517}}</ref> a claim that has been tested in two studies. In a 2016 Australian study, when markers were asked to mark a set of contract cheating assignments and contract cheating was not mentioned to them, no marker raised any concerns of contract cheating.<ref name="Lines 889–914"/> However, in a later study when markers were specifically asked to detect it, they correctly identified contract cheating 62% of the time.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dawson|first=Phillip|last2=Sutherland-Smith|first2=Wendy|date=2017-06-05|title=Can markers detect contract cheating? Results from a pilot study|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/02602938.2017.1336746|journal=Assessment & Evaluation in Higher Education|volume=0|issue=0|pages=1–8|doi=10.1080/02602938.2017.1336746|issn=0260-2938}}</ref>
It has recently been proposed that existing assignment and invigilated assessment data can be systematically analyzed in order to detect patterns of students' performance that may be indicative of contract cheating.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Clare|first=Joseph|last2=Walker|first2=Sonia|last3=Hobson|first3=Julia|date=2017-08-08|title=Can we detect contract cheating using existing assessment data? Applying crime prevention theory to an academic integrity issue|url=https://edintegrity.springeropen.com/articles/10.1007/s40979-017-0015-4|journal=International Journal for Educational Integrity|language=En|volume=13|issue=1|pages=4|doi=10.1007/s40979-017-0015-4|issn=1833-2595}}</ref> Additionally, at the Plagiarism across Europe and Beyond conference, it was demonstrated how collecting analytical data at the time of writing can help in identifying cases where a student committed contract cheating. <ref>{{cite conference |url= https://plagiarism.pefka.mendelu.cz/files/proceedings_15.pdf |title=Plagiarism detection 2.0: Detection of Contract Cheating |last1=Khan |first1=Wasi |year=2015|publisher= Mendel University|book-title= |pages=215|location=Brno |conference= Plagiarism Across Europe and Beyond }}</ref> <ref>{{cite AV media| people = Khan, Wasi (Presenter)| date = Aug 3, 2015| title = Plagiarism Across Europe and Beyond| medium = Motion picture| language = English | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=14f5AnfTy0A | access-date = November 12, 2017| location = Brno, Czech Republic | publisher = Plagiarism Across Europe and Beyond }}</ref>
Although non-originality engines (like [[Turnitin]]) are unlikely to detect contract cheating, there has been some success in using them to identify the source of assignments detected on auction sites.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.heacademy.ac.uk/resources/detail/stem-conference-2014/Post_event_resources/Computing/Using_Turnitin|title=Using Turnitin as a tool for attribution in cases of contract cheating|last2=Lancaster|first2=Thomas|date=2014-04-13|first1=Robert|last1=Clarke|accessdate=2014-10-28}}</ref>
==Penalties== In general, academic institutions consider contract cheating to be one of the most serious forms of academic misconduct and it is penalised accordingly. In 2010 the 'AMBeR Project' developed a UK 'Plagiarism Tariff' in an attempt to standardise penalties for all forms of academic misconduct. The final report noted that purchase of an assignment should be penalised with the most serious penalties available, such as expulsion from the institution, and that many institutions considered it to be a separate form of misconduct altogether due to the seemingly obvious intent associated with it.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/news/plagiarism-tariff-let-the-punishment-fit-the-demerit-points/412088.article|title=Plagiarism tariff: let the punishment fit the demerit points|work=Times Higher Education (THE)|accessdate=22 May 2016}}</ref> However, a 2015 research study, also in the UK, asked university students what they thought penalties for academic misconduct should be. The responses demonstrated that students consistently recommended lenient penalties for plagiarism, and that this effect was most pronounced for contract cheating.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://cronfa.swan.ac.uk/Record/cronfa20205|title=Academic integrity: a quantitative study of confidence and understanding in students at the start of their higher education|publisher=|accessdate=22 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/news/hundreds-fail-to-spot-plagiarism/2019818.article|title=Hundreds fail to spot plagiarism|work=Times Higher Education (THE)|accessdate=22 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/02602938.2015.1024199#.VccNJvma5kU|title= Academic integrity: a quantitative study of confidence and understanding in students at the start of their higher education|accessdate=22 May 2016 | doi=10.1080/02602938.2015.1024199|volume=41|journal=Assessment & Evaluation in Higher Education|pages=482–497}}</ref>
==Legality== The legality of contract cheating services was reviewed by Newton and Lang in a 2016 book chapter of the Springer Handbook for Academic Integrity.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://link.springer.com/referenceworkentry/10.1007/978-981-287-098-8_38|title=Handbook of Academic Integrity|first1=Philip M.|last1=Newton|first2=Christopher|last2=Lang|editor-first=Tracey|editor-last=Bretag|date=1 January 2016|publisher=Springer Singapore|pages=249–271|via=link.springer.com|doi=10.1007/978-981-287-098-8_38}}</ref> The legal status of these services varies internationally. In [[New Zealand]] it is illegal to "advertise or provide third party assistance to cheat", with similar, older laws on the statutes of 17 states in the US.
In the United Kingdom, the Quality Assurance Agency published a report<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.qaa.ac.uk/newsroom/education-deterrence-detection-how-to-tackle-the-problem-of-essay-mills|title=Education, deterrence, detection: how to tackle the problem of essay mills|date=2016-08-18|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160919071215/http://www.qaa.ac.uk/newsroom/education-deterrence-detection-how-to-tackle-the-problem-of-essay-mills|archivedate=19 September 2016|work=QAA news}}</ref> advocating the use of a legal approach as one way to tackle contract cheating, and suggesting that existing fraud laws might be used, since the activities of such services, and their clients, could be reasonably interpreted to fit with definitions of fraud as they involve 'false representation' and 'failure to disclose information'. A subsequent research project<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://edintegrity.springeropen.com/articles/10.1007/s40979-017-0014-5|title=Are Essay Mills committing fraud? An analysis of their behaviours vs the 2006 Fraud Act (UK)|publisher=|journal=International Journal for Educational Integrity|volume=13|issue=1|pages=3|doi=10.1007/s40979-017-0014-5}}</ref> compared the UK Fraud laws with the terms and conditions used by contract cheating services and concluded that they would be unlikely to fall foul of [[Fraud]] law due to the disclaimers, terms and conditions they use which generally state that any custom written products are to be used only as 'study guides' or 'revision aids', thereby placing responsibility, and 'intent', onto the student client. Despite this, media 'stings' have shown that companies can be complicit in the inappropriate use of these products.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/news/article1422913.ece|title=‘£630 and I’ll put you on the way to a first’|date=15 June 2014|author1=Robin Henry|author2=Cal Flyn|author3=Katie Glass|publisher=The Sunday Times}}</ref> A similar analysis in [[Lithuania]]<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://edintegrity.springeropen.com/articles/10.1007/s40979-017-0020-7|title=Ethical and legal observations on contract cheating services as an agreement|publisher=|journal=International Journal for Educational Integrity|volume=13|issue=1|pages=9|doi=10.1007/s40979-017-0020-7}}</ref> concluded that contract cheating services were unlikely to fall foul of existing laws, although an analysis of [[Australian]]<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/1037969X17710627|title=Contract cheating: Will students pay for serious criminal consequences?|date=18 September 2017|publisher=|journal=Alternative Law Journal|volume=42|issue=2|pages=123–129|doi=10.1177/1037969x17710627}}</ref> law concluded that fraud, as well as forgery and conspiracy, might be legal avenues via which contract cheating could be targeted. All three studies called for the introduction of new legal approaches to tackle contract cheating.
A follow-up research study<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://edintegrity.springeropen.com/articles/10.1007/s40979-017-0022-5|title=A legal approach to tackling contract cheating?|publisher=|journal=International Journal for Educational Integrity|volume=13|issue=1|pages=11|doi=10.1007/s40979-017-0022-5}}</ref> proposed such a new law, based on the principle of [[strict liability]], which lessens the requirement for prosecutors to demonstrate that they 'intended to help student cheat', but instead would make them liable for prosecution simply for offering services that could be reasonably interpreted as being used for contract cheating.
More broadly, despite the apparent potential of a legal challenge to contract cheating companies, prosecutions are currently rare, largely due to the limitations of existing laws. In addition, the simple act of outlawing a service would not necessarily reduce demand for it; the aforementioned research studies all call for a holistic, multi-pronged approach to tackling contract cheating.
==See also== *[[Accreditation mill]] • [[Diploma mill]] • [[Ordination mill]] • Contract cheating / [[Essay mill]] * [[Author mill]] • [[Vanity publishing]]

{{DISPLAYTITLE:''Dead Man Walking'' (book)}} [[File:AngolaLAPrison.jpg|thumb|[[Louisiana State Penitentiary]], the setting of the work]] '''''Dead Man Walking''''' (1993) is a work of non-fiction by Sister [[Helen Prejean]], a [[Roman Catholic nun]] and one of the [[Sisters of Saint Joseph of Medaille]] based in New Orleans. Arising from her work as a spiritual adviser to two convicted murderers on [[Death Row]], the book is set largely at the [[Louisiana State Penitentiary]] (Angola) in [[West Feliciana Parish, Louisiana]]. It examines moral issues related to the men's acknowledgement of their crimes and to the state's use of the death penalty.<ref>Schaller, Linda. "[https://www.pbs.org/kqed/onenight/about/producer.html The Producer's Journey]." [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]]. Retrieved on September 1, 2010.</ref>
==Background== Prejean has become a leading American advocate for the abolition of the death penalty. Her campaign was initiated following her correspondence and visits that she maintained with two convicted murderers. She started this ministry in 1982. The first man was [[Elmo Patrick Sonnier]], who was sentenced to death by electric chair. She visited Sonnier in prison and agreed to be his spiritual adviser in the months leading up to his death. The second was [[Robert Lee Willie]], for whom she also served as spiritual adviser.
Prejean gained insight into the minds of these convicted murderers and the process involved in executions, including its effects on the prison guards and other personnel. She became convinced that the state's use of the death penalty was morally wrong and began speaking out against [[capital punishment]]. At the same time, she founded ''Survive'', an organization devoted to providing counseling to the families of victims of violence.
==Name== The title of the book comes from a phrase once traditional in American prisons, to designate a man condemned to death. They were held on what was known as Death Row, deprived of most social contact and unable to work or participate in prison programs. Prior to the 1960s, when guards would lead a condemned man down the prison hallway, they would call out, "Dead man walking! Dead man walking here!" The origin of the phrase is debated. It may have been to warn other staff or prisoners, to let them know they should be on their guard since a [[death row]] prisoner has nothing to lose and could be violent. It may also have been a kind of [[honorific]] declamation, to let other prisoners know that they should move out of the way - death row prisoners being seen as an [[elite]] within the prison system. Alternatively, the call may have been a [[Social stigma|stigma]] attached to the condemned man, to remind others within earshot not to touch him in order not to catch his bad luck. In any case, its symbolism is clear: the condemned prisoner, in the eyes of the law, was dead already.
==Adaptations==
===Film=== {{Main article|Dead Man Walking (film)}} In 1995, a film based on the book was made, starring [[Susan Sarandon]] and [[Sean Penn]].
===Opera=== {{Main article|Dead Man Walking (opera)}} The book was adapted as an [[Dead Man Walking (opera)|opera]] of the same name, composed by [[Jake Heggie]] with a libretto by playwright [[Terrence McNally]]. It premiered at the [[San Francisco Opera]] in October 2000. The international premiere of the opera was in August 2003, in Adelaide. It has been produced in several other cities, including by the [[Union Avenue Opera]] in St. Louis, Missouri.
===Stage version of the book/film=== {{Main article|Dead Man Walking (play)}}

{{about|bridges with a corresponding Devil-related myth or folktale|other uses}}
{{Refimprove|date=August 2009}} [[File:Ponte_del_Diavolo,_Valli_di_Lanzo,_Lanzo_Torinese1.jpg|275px|thumb|Devil's Bridge (Italian: ''Ponte del Diavolo'') in [[Lanzo Torinese]], northern Italy.]] [[File:Teufelsbrücke01.jpg|thumb|275px|''[[Teufelsbrücke]]'' of [[St Gotthard Pass]], Switzerland.]] '''Devil's Bridge''' is a term applied to dozens of ancient [[bridge]]s, found primarily in [[Europe]]. Most of these bridges are stone or [[masonry]] [[arch bridge]]s and represent a significant technological achievement. Each of the Devil's Bridges has a corresponding [[Devil]]-related myth or folktale.
Local lore often wrongly attributes these bridges to the [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] era, but in fact many of them are [[Middle Ages|medieval]], having been built between 1000 and 1600 AD.{{cn|date=May 2016}} In medieval times [[Devil's Causeway|some Roman roads]] were themselves considered beyond human capabilities and needs, and therefore had to have been built by the devil.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}}
==Associated legends== [[File:Little Devil's Bridge over the Russ, above Altdorft, Swiss-d, from Liber Studiorum, part IV.jpg|thumb|left|''Little Devil's Bridge'' (1809) by [[J. M. W. Turner]]]] [[File:Pont du Diable - Céret.JPG|275px|thumb|[[Pont du Diable (Céret)|Pont du Diable]] in [[Céret]], southern France]] The bridges that fall into the Devil's Bridge category are so numerous that the legends about them form a special category in the [[Aarne-Thompson classification system]] for [[folklore|folktales]] (Number 1191).<ref>{{cite web |author=D. L. Ashliman |authorlink=D. L. Ashliman|url=http://www.pitt.edu/~dash/type1191.html |title=The Devil's Bridge: folktales of Aarne-Thompson-Uther type 1191 |type=private website |publisher=D. L. Ashliman |date= |location=Pittsburgh, USA |accessdate=2016-10-03}}</ref>{{rs?|reson=personal website, lacking of public recognition?|date=October 2016}} Some legends have elements of related folktale categories, for example Deceiving the [[Devil]] (AT #1196), The Devil's Contract (AT #756B), and The Master Builder legends.{{cn|date=May 2016}}
One version of the tale presents the bridge builder and the Devil as adversaries. This reflects the fact that frequently, such as in the case of the ''[[Teufelsbrücke]]'' at the [[St Gotthard Pass]], these bridges were built under such challenging conditions that successful completion of the bridge required a [[hero]]ic effort on the part of the builders and the community, ensuring its legendary status.
Other versions of the legend feature an old lady or a simple [[herder]] who makes a [[deal with the Devil|pact with the Devil]]. In this version the devil agrees to build the bridge, and in return he will receive the first [[soul]] to cross it.
After building the bridge (often overnight) the devil is outwitted by his adversary, for example by throwing bread to lure a dog over the bridge first, and is last seen descending into the water, bringing peace to the community.
In the case of the ''[[Stone Bridge (Regensburg)#Legend|Steinerne Brücke]]'' in [[Regensburg]], the legend speaks of the devil helping in a race between the builders of the bridge and of the cathedral (in fact a significantly later construction), and a slight bump in the middle of the bridge is said to result from the devil's leaping with rage upon being tricked out of his prize.
In the legend of ''[[Teufelsbrück]]'' in [[Hamburg]], which only leads over a small stream, the carpenter had a pact with the devil, and he promised him the first soul crossing the bridge. On the day of inauguration, while the priest and county councillor debated who should step on the bridge first, a rabbit crossed it and the disappointed devil disappeared. A statue refers to the legend there.
The legend of [[Ponte della Maddalena]] in [[Borgo a Mozzano]], Province of [[Lucca]], tells of a local saint, often [[Julian the Hospitaller|Saint Julian, the Hospitaller]], who made the pact with the devil<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Chronicles of Julian, the Hospitaller|last=Bernardi|first=Eduardo|publisher=Higuma Limited|year=2018|isbn=978-0-473-43697-1|location=New Zealand|pages=Books 1-5}}</ref>. On the day of delivery, the saint sets fire to a dog or a pig that crosses the bridge and deceives the devil.
Most of the bridges that have received the Devil's Bridge appellation are remarkable in some regard, most often for the technological hurdles surpassed in building the bridge, but on occasion for its [[aesthetics|aesthetic]] grace as well, or for its [[economics|economic]] or strategic importance to the community it serves.{{cn|date=May 2016}}
==Devil's Bridges (incomplete list)== [[File:Devils-bridge-pano.JPG|thumb|275px|The three bridges of [[Devil's Bridge, Ceredigion]], [[Wales]]]] [[File:Rakotzbrücke.jpg|thumb|Rakotzbrücke, [[Azalea and Rhododendron Park Kromlau]] – [[Saxony]], Germany]]
===France=== There are 49 Devil's Bridges in France,<ref>{{cite book |author=Graham Robb |title=The Discovery of France |page=131 |publisher=Picador |date=2007 |location=Hampshire, England |isbn=978-0-330-42761-6}}</ref> including: *[[Pont du Diable, Hérault|Pont du Diable]] – Aniane (Gorges de l'Hérault, [[Languedoc-Roussillon]]) *Pont du Diable – [[Villemagne-l'Argentière]] ([[Hérault]], [[Languedoc-Roussillon]]) *Pont du Diable – [[Beaugency]] *[[Pont du Diable (Céret)|Pont du Diable]] – [[Céret]] *[[Pont du Diable (Ariège)|Pont du Diable]] – [[Foix]] *Pont du Diable – [[Olargues]] *[[Pont Valentré|Pont du Diable]] – [[Cahors|Valentré]] *Pont du Diable – Crouzet Migette *[[Point du Diable (Ariège)|Point du Diable]] – [[Ariège (department)|Ariège]]
===Germany=== *Rakotzbrücke, [[Azalea and Rhododendron Park Kromlau]] – [[Saxony]], Germany *Bridge near [[Bamberg Cathedral]], Germany (similar legend){{cn|date=October 2016}} *{{Interlanguage link multi|Brickegickel|de}} – [[Frankfurt]], Germany (similar legend){{cn|date=October 2016}} *[[Teufelsbrück]] – [[Hamburg]], Germany *[[Stone Bridge (Regensburg)|Steinerne Brücke]] – [[Regensburg]], Germany (similar legend)
===Italy=== *Ponte del Diavolo – [[Ascoli Piceno]], [[Marche]] *Ponte del Diavolo – [[Blera]], [[Lazio]] *Ponte del Diavolo (officially Ponte Vecchio, also Ponte Gobbo) – [[Bobbio]], [[Emilia Romagna]] *[[Ponte della Maddalena|Ponte del Diavolo]] (or Ponte della Maddalena) – [[Borgo a Mozzano]], [[Tuscany]] *Ponte del Diavolo – Cavallara (a frazione of [[Gualdo Cattaneo]], [[Umbria]]) *Ponte del Diavolo – [[Cividale]], [[Friuli]] *Ponte del Diavolo – [[Civita, Calabria|Civita]], [[Calabria]] *Ponte del Diavolo (''Su ponti de su tiaulu'' or ''Su ponti de is aremigus'') – [[Decimomannu]], [[Sardinia]] *Ponte del Diavolo (''Ponte Vecchio'') – [[Dronero]], [[Province of Cuneo]], [[Piedmont]] *Ponte del Diavolo – [[Lanzo Torinese]], [[Piedmont]] *Ponticello del Diavolo – [[Torcello]], [[Veneto]]
===Portugal=== *[[Ponte da Mizarela]] – [[Braga District]], [[Portugal]]
===Slovenia=== *Hudičev most – [[Bohinj]], [[Slovenia]] *Hudičev most – [[Tolmin]], [[Slovenia]]

page.title: Don Pedro of Toledo Kissing Henry IV's Sword

revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:IngresPedroKissSwordOfHenri4.jpg|thumb|240px|''Don Pedro of Toledo Kissing Henry IV's Sword'', 1819 version, [[château de Pau]]]] [[File:Jean Auguste Dominique Ingres - The Sword of Henry IV - WGA11851.jpg|thumb|240px|''Don Pedro of Toledo Kissing Henry IV's Sword'', 1832, the [[Louvre]]]] '''''Don Pedro of Toledo Kissing Henry IV's Sword''''' is an 1814 painting in the [[Troubador style]] by the French artist [[Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres]], showing the Spanish ambassador [[Pedro Álvarez de Toledo, 5th Marquis of Villafranca]] kissing the sword of [[Henry IV of France]] (held by a young page) in the salle des Caryatides of the Louvre palace. The painting is now lost. Between 1819 and 1832, Ingres painted three additional paintings of the subject. ==History== Episodes from the life of Henri IV were a frequent subject for French painters in Ingres' time.Condon, Patricia; Cohn, Marjorie B.; Mongan, Agnes (1983). ''In Pursuit of Perfection: The Art of J.-A.-D. Ingres''. Louisville: The J. B. Speed Art Museum. p. 238. {{ISBN|0-9612276-0-5}}. The incident depicted in this painting was described by Ingres in one of his notebooks:
One day Don Pedro of Toledo, the Ambassador of Spain to the court of Henri IV, saw in the Louvre the sword of the King in the hands of a young page. Advancing, he knelt on the ground and kissed it, rendering honor, he said, to the most glorious sword in Christendom.
The artist painted four versions of the subject between 1814 and 1832. The original version was painted in 1814 and exhibited at the Paris Salon that year, where it was disparaged by critics.Radius, Emilio (1968). ''L'opera completa di Ingres''. Milan: Rizzoli. p. 96. {{OCLC|58818848}} After even Ingres' friends found fault with it, Ingres reworked in 1820. The revised composition included the figures of the [[Jean Louis de Nogaret de La Valette|Duc d'Epernon]] and [[Gabrielle d'Estrées]] behind the ambassador and the page.Condon, Patricia; Cohn, Marjorie B.; Mongan, Agnes (1983). ''In Pursuit of Perfection: The Art of J.-A.-D. Ingres''. Louisville: The J. B. Speed Art Museum. p. 78. {{ISBN|0-9612276-0-5}} The location of the painting since the mid-19th century is unknown. The composition of the painting before its revision is recorded in an engraving by Achille Réveil published in 1851. A second version (1819; now at the [[château de Pau]]){{cite web|url=http://chateau-pau.fr/objet/don-pedro-de-tolede-baisant-lepee-dhenri-iv|title=Don Pedro de Tolède baisant l'épée d'Henri IV | Château de Pau|publisher=chateau-pau.fr|accessdate=2015-02-05}} was painted for Ingres' friend, the artist Jean Alaux. It closely replicates the initial composition of the 1814 version: In the background at the left stands a guard; an unidentified figure is exiting at the right. This version was displayed in the 2014 ''L'invention du Passé. Histoires de cœur et d'épée 1802–1850'' exhibition at the [[musée des beaux-arts de Lyon]]. In the third painting (1820; acquired for the [[Louvre Abu Dhabi]] in 2009),{{cite web|url=http://www.latribunedelart.com/premieres-acquisitions-du-louvre-abou-dhabi|title=Premières acquisitions du Louvre-Abou Dhabi - La Tribune de l'Art|publisher=latribunedelart.com|accessdate=2015-02-05}} Ingres moved the row of caryatids from the left edge of the composition to the center, and reversed the angle of the perspective. The figures of the Duc d'Epernon and Gabrielle d'Estrées are once again in the background at the left. The painting was previously in a private collection in [[Oslo]].{{cite web|url=http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/joconde_fr?ACTION=CHERCHER&FIELD_98=REF&VALUE_98=00000060300|title=Joconde - catalogue - dictionnaires|publisher=culture.gouv.fr|accessdate=2015-02-05}} The fourth version (1832; acquired by the [[Louvre Museum]] in 1981)Condon, Patricia; Cohn, Marjorie B.; Mongan, Agnes (1983). ''In Pursuit of Perfection: The Art of J.-A.-D. Ingres''. Louisville: The J. B. Speed Art Museum. pp. 80–81. {{ISBN|0-9612276-0-5}} is slightly smaller than the others. The setting is changed from the Salle des Caryatides to the Stairway of Henri II, and the number of onlookers is augmented by the inclusion of the poet [[François de Malherbe]], Cardinal [[Jacques Davy Duperron]], and an unidentified man. ==References== {{Jean Auguste Dominique Ingres}} [[Category:1814 paintings]] [[Category:Paintings by Jean Auguste Dominique Ingres]] [[Category:Paintings of the Louvre by French artists]] [[Category:History paintings]]

{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox play | name = Feet of Flames | image = Flatley in blue.jpg | music = [[Ronan Hardiman]] | director = [[Michael Flatley]] | basis = | productions = | premiere = 1998 | premiere_location = [[Hyde Park, London|Hyde Park]], London (1998), [[Ferenc Puskás Stadium (1953)|Nepstadion]], Budapest (2000 World Tour) | genre = [[Irish Dance]] | awards = <!-- Please do not include production-specific (acting, directing, etc.) awards --> }}
'''''Feet of Flames''''' is an [[Irish dance]] show directed by [[Michael Flatley]] and scored by [[Ronan Hardiman]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/1464172.stm BBC]</ref> Flatley was known for the shows ''[[Riverdance]]'' and ''[[Lord of the Dance (musical)|Lord of the Dance]]''.
==History== ===Hyde Park 1998=== The Hyde Park show was first created as a one-off performance of Flatley's previous show, "Lord of the Dance". It premiered on 25 July 1998, playing to approximately 25,000 people at the Route of Kings, an open-space arena-like spot in London's [[Hyde Park, London|Hyde Park]]. Although closely resembling its predecessor, this show merged troupes, added new numbers, and featured a multi-level stage for the finale as well as a live band. Amongst the new numbers is Flatley's solo – "Feet of Flames", which the show is based around. The show introduced some of the key elements that are now featured when Flatley performs. His silver-heeled shoes made by [[Freed's of London]] were used for the first time in this show. TV screens on both sides of the stage were installed and are now used in all the shows that feature Flatley. Film of the Hyde Park show was later distributed on VHS and DVD.
===2000 World Tour=== On 21 September 1999 Michael Flatley announced a "Feet of Flames" world tour for 2000. This tour began on Wednesday, 1 March 2000, in Germany. The show differed significantly from the original 1998 version. The show had new numbers, new leads, a new story line and a "whole new outlook" in the words of Flatley.{{Citation needed|date=July 2008}} Both the original female leads [[Bernadette Flynn]] and [[Gillian Norris]] were replaced by Sarah Clark and [[Leigh Ann McKenna]]. [[Daire Nolan]] was replaced by [[Stephen Brunning]]. Both Daire Nolan and Gillian Norris went on to pursue their own careers after the 1998 show. Bernadette Flynn left to dance with Lord of the Dance troupe one until 2001. Some of the characters changed slightly in the show. Lord of the Dance became Firespirit, Saroise became The Swan and Morrighan the Temptress became Cleopatra. The Dark Lord was remained but there are sayings that they still used Don Dorcha as the name. Helen Egan's part as the little spirit became the Court Jester in the World Tour. The Highlight of the 2000 tour was Flatley and the Troupe performing in [[Budapest]] to over 100,000 people. The European part of the 2000 World Tour concluded on 29 July 2000 in [[Stormont Castle]], [[Belfast]], Northern Ireland.
===2001 "Victory Tour"===
The 2001 tour, dubbed the "USA Victory Tour", had a preview show on 6 June 2001 in the [[Bi-Lo Center]], [[Greenville, South Carolina]]. The tour officially began on 8 June 2001 in the [[AmericanAirlines Arena]], [[Miami, Florida]]. The highlight of the tour was Michael Flatley performing for the first time in [[Madison Square Garden]] in New York City on 29 June 2001. The tour ended on 29 July 2001 in [[Dallas, Texas]] in the [[American Airlines Center]], the second event to be held at the venue. The last time the show was performed was 29 July 2001. Michael Flatley was said to have retired that night{{Citation needed|date=July 2008}} but later in 2005 would come out with a new show, [[Celtic Tiger Live|Celtic Tiger]].
===2008 and 2009 Tour=== "Feet of Flames" returned to the world stage for a brief period with lead dancers Damien O' Kane and Bernadette Flynn taking the lead. This would mark the first time in the show's history that Michael Flatley would not be starring or dancing in it. This show featured dances/costumes from 1998 Hyde Park show. Later in 2009 Flatley returned in the lead role.
===2009=== In 2009, Michael Flatley reprised his role in the 2009 tour held in the [[Taipei Arena]] in [[Taipei]], Taiwan. It was filmed for DVD and later released as noted in his website. It was also released on Amazon.com and Amazon.co.uk by Playback HD in 2010. The 2009 return of Michael Flatley would later mark his return to his show, Lord of the Dance in 2010.
==CD, VHS and DVD releases== [[File:Flatley alone cropped.jpg|thumb|200px|Flatley as Lord of the Dance during his return]] The "Feet of Flames" show from Hyde Park in 1998 was released on VHS and DVD. A CD of the new music from the Hyde park show was released with the DVD. The Budapest show in 2000 was recorded for DVD release but this did not happen; however, clips of the show were put on Michael Flatley's autobiography/concert DVD ''[[Michael Flatley Gold]]''. Included on the DVD are the numbers:
*The Court of High Kings *Firedance *Cleopatra's Spell *Thunder and Lightning *Stolen Kiss *The Duel *Victory March/Victory Dance *Feet of Flames solo
The [[Madison Square Garden]] show on 29 June 2001 in New York City and the American Airlines Center show on 29 July 2001 in [[Dallas]], Texas, were recorded. The American leg of the tour was filmed for an [[IMAX]] planned for release in 2002. In addition parts of the footage were going to be used in a film featuring Michael Flatley.{{Citation needed|date=July 2008}} The working title for the film was supposedly "Dream Dancer", a fictional love story.{{Citation needed|date=July 2008}} Clips of the rehearsal process for the movie can be found on ''[[Michael Flatley Gold]]''. The film was, however, never completed. The original film from the shows in allegedly tied up in ownership dispute between the filming company and Michael Flatley's company [[Unicorn Entertainment]].{{Citation needed|date=July 2008}}
The 2009 Taiwan tour was filmed for an actual DVD release and later released on Amazon.com and Amazon.co.uk in 2010
The chanting of the monks from the "Court of High Kings" (Victory Tour) is sampled on the first track of Michael Flatley's flute album "On A Different Note", which was released on March 2011.

{{Italic title}} {{Infobox artwork | title = Flamingo | image_file = Calder Flamingo.jpg | painting_alignment = right | image_size = 300px | alt = Calder's ''Flamingo'' in Chicago's Federal Plaza. | type = painted steel stabile | artist = [[Alexander Calder]] | year = October 25, 1974 | height_metric = | width_metric = | height_imperial = 636 | width_imperial = | city = [[Chicago]] | museum = | coordinates = {{coord|41.87881|-87.62967|type:landmark_region:US-IL|display=title}} | pushpin_map = Chicago | pushpin_map_caption= Location in Chicago | map_size = | owner = [[General Services Administration]]<ref>http://collections.si.edu/search/results.htm?q=flamingo+calder</ref> }} '''''Flamingo''''', created by noted [[Americans|American]] artist [[Alexander Calder]], is a {{convert|53|ft|adj=on}}<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chipublib.org/004chicago/timeline/calder.html |title=Chicago Public Library |accessdate=2007-05-04}}</ref> tall stabile located in the Federal Plaza in front of the [[Kluczynski Federal Building]] in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=1N83264W7X277.2656&profile=ariall&uri=full=3100001~!5142~!32&ri=1&aspect=Browse&menu=search&source=~!siartinventories&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=Outdoor+Sculpture+--+Illinois+--+Chicago&index=&uindex=&aspect=Browse&menu=search&ri=1|accessdate=2007-07-01|year=2004|publisher=Smithsonian Institution|title=Art Inventories Catalogue}}</ref> It was commissioned by the United States [[General Services Administration]] and was unveiled in 1974, although Calder's signature on the sculpture indicates it was constructed in 1973.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://chicago.about.com/cs/art/l/blsculpturescal.htm |title=about.com Chicago |accessdate=2007-05-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070816034026/http://chicago.about.com/cs/art/l/blsculpturescal.htm |archivedate=2007-08-16 |df= }}</ref>
==Attributes== [[File:Flamingo Calder.jpg|thumb|left|''Flamingo'' as seen in front of the Kluczynski Federal Building]]
''Flamingo'' weighs 50 tons, is composed of [[steel]], and is [[vermilion]] in color. Calder gave the stabile its color, which has come to be called "Calder red",<ref name="pag">{{cite web |url=http://www.winterdelights.com/pdfs/publicart.pdf |format=PDF |title=The Chicago Public Art Guide |author=City of Chicago Department of Public Affairs |accessdate=2007-05-04}}</ref> to offset it from the black and steel surroundings of nearby office buildings, including the [[Ludwig Mies van der Rohe]]-designed Kluczynski Federal Building.<ref name="higdon">{{cite web |url=http://www.halhigdon.com/picasso/index.htm |author=Higdon, Hal |title=Starting with Picasso: Chicago's Finest Art Isn't All in the Art Institute |accessdate=2007-05-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://antiquesandthearts.com/archive/calder.htm |author=May, Stephen |title=Alexander Calder at the National Gallery of Art |accessdate=2007-05-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070405023716/http://www.antiquesandthearts.com/archive/calder.htm |archivedate=2007-04-05 |df= }}</ref> The stabile is an art form which Calder pioneered. It is an abstract structure that is completely stationary, as opposed to a [[mobile (sculpture)|mobile]], which can move with [[air current]]s. In 2012, the sculpture was repainted using the historic "Calder Red" color.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://sculptureconservation.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/CALDER-RED-PDF.pdf|title = NOTES FOR A HISTORY OF “CALDER RED” COLOR AND ITS PAINTS IN THE UNITED STATES IN RELATION TO THE RECOATINGS OF ALEXANDER CALDER’S FLAMINGO (1973) AND LA GRANDE VITESSE (1969) AND OTHER CALDER STABILES|date = 2013|accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = Lodge|first = Robert}}</ref>
==Commissioning and unveiling== Calder was commissioned to design the sculpture because of his well-established international [[reputation]]; the space, surrounded by rectangular [[modern architecture|modern]] buildings, necessitated the kind of [[arch]]ing forms and dynamic surfaces that a large-scale Calder stabile could provide.<ref>{{cite journal |last=[[Joan Marter]] |first= |date=July 1979 |title=Alexander Calder's Stabiles: Monumental Public Sculpture in America |journal=American Art Journal |volume=11 |issue=3 |pages=75–85 |doi=10.2307/1594168 |jstor=1594168 |publisher=American Art Journal, Vol. 11, No. 3}}</ref> ''Flamingo'' was the first work of art commissioned by the General Services Administration under the federal [[Percent for Art]] program, which allocates a percentage of a project's budget to public art.<ref name="calder">{{cite web |url=http://www.calder.org/SETS/life/life.html |title=Calder Foundation: Calder's Life |accessdate=2007-05-04 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070416222346/http://www.calder.org/SETS/life/life.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-04-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |url=http://forecastpublicart.org/anthology-downloads/wetenhall.pdf |format=PDF |last=Wetenhall |first=John |date=Fall–Winter 1993 |title=A Brief History of Percent-for-Art in America |journal=Public Art Review |issue=9 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726061624/http://forecastpublicart.org/anthology-downloads/wetenhall.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-26 |df= }}</ref> Calder unveiled the model for ''Flamingo'' on April 23, 1973 at the [[Art Institute of Chicago]]; the sculpture was presented to the public for the first time on October 25, 1974, at the same time that Calder's ''Universe'' mobile was unveiled at what was then known as the Sears Tower (now the [[Willis Tower]]). The day was proclaimed "Alexander Calder Day" and featured a circus parade.<ref name="calder"/>
==Spatial relationships== [[Image:CalderFlamingo3.jpg|thumb|right|''Flamingo'' as viewed from the Willis Tower skydeck]]
Despite the massive size of the sculpture, its design is such that viewers can walk underneath and around it, thus enabling one to perceive it in human scale.<ref name="pag"/> The shape of ''Flamingo'' alludes to the natural and animal realm, which is a stark contrast to more literal interpretations in sculpture from previous decades.<ref>{{Cite news |last=[[Joan Marter]] |first=|date=July–August 1998 |title=The Legacy of Alexander Calder |magazine=Sculpture |volume=17 |issue=6}}</ref>
Calder's structure is a prominent example of the [[Constructivism (art)|constructivist]] movement, first popularized in Russia in the early 20th century. Constructivism refers to sculpture that is made from smaller pieces which are joined together.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Hubbard |first=Guy |date=January 2002 |title=Constructivism |magazine=Arts & Activities |volume=130 |issue=6 |page=37}}</ref>
A [[maquette]] of the stabile was formerly displayed inside the Loop Station [[post office]] in the Federal Plaza.<ref name="higdon"/> It currently resides in the Art Institute of Chicago's Modern Wing.

{{Infobox person | name = Georges Mora | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Gunter Morawski | birth_date = {{Birth date|1913|06|26}} | birth_place = [[Leipzig]], German Empire | death_date ={{Death date and age|1992|06|07|1913|06|26}} | death_place = [[Melbourne]], Australia | nationality = | other_names = Georges Morand | occupation = Art Dealer | years_active = 1954-1992 | known_for = Mentorship of Australian artists, establishment of Tolarno Galleries | notable_works = | spouse = [[Mirka Mora]] (m.1947, div.1979), Caroline Williams (m.1985) | partner = <!-- (unmarried long-term partner) --> | children = [[Philippe Mora|Philippe]] (b.1949), William (b.1953), [[Tiriel Mora|Tiriel]] (b.1958), Sam (b.1985) }}
'''Georges Mora''' (June 26, 1913 – June 7, 1992) was a German-born Australian entrepreneur, art dealer, patron, connoisseur and restaurateur.
== Early life == Mora was born '''Gunter Morawski''' on June 26, 1913 in [[Leipzig]], Germany, of Jewish Polish heritage. As a young medical student Mora became a member of a communist cell and fled Germany to Paris in 1930. When the [[Spanish Civil War]] broke out, Georges left Paris to join the cause. After a plane crash, he was a prisoner of war for a short time. He was active in the [[French Resistance]] in World War II, using the alias Georges Morand. After the War, Georges worked as a patent dealer and became the director of a Jewish rehabilitation home for children run by [[Œuvre de secours aux enfants]] (OSE) in Paris.<ref>unverified account from his biography on the Georges Mora Foundation website [http://www.georgesmorafoundation.org.au/biography.html]</ref> Later In 1947 he married Parisian artist and fellow Jewish [[refugee]] [[Mirka Mora|Mirka Zelik]], becoming a French citizen.
== New York and Melbourne == In 1949, after the birth of Georges' and Mirka's first son [[Philippe Mora]] (a filmmaker) they joined his family in New York, then in July 1951 moved on to McKinnon, Melbourne<ref>Daniel Thomas, in 'Creative Displacements: Georges Mora, Rudy Komon, Joseph Brown', in ''Art and Australia'', Vol 30 No 4 Winter 1993, p. 481, recounts that they were attracted to Australia; "because his wife, Mirka, had read [in] Murger's ''Scènes de la Vie de Bohème'' [of] a character, the photographer Antoine Fauchery, who had been in Melbourne and Mirka declared, 'Melbourne is so attractive to the French'"</ref> where he adopted the name Georges Mora. With characteristic adaptability he took up management of a [[matzo]] factory. Seeking more romantic quarters Georges and Mirka moved into [[Grosvenor Chambers]] ([[Ola Cohn]]'s former studio) at 9 Collins Street Melbourne (the so called 'Paris End'). Recognising that their hospitality and cuisine were marketable, the Moras opened a coffee lounge. In 1954, 'Mirka Café' was the first in Melbourne where patrons could eat at tables on the pavement in the Parisian style and the café became the watering-hole of Melbourne's avant-garde.<ref>Daniel Thomas. 'Creative Displacements: Georges Mora, Rudy Komon, Joseph Brown', in ''Art and Australia'', Vol 30 No 4 Winter 1993, p. 481</ref><ref>Toby Creswell, Samantha Trenoweth (2006) ''1001 Australians You Should Know''. Australia: Pluto Press. p. 362-3</ref> Patrons ate from Expressionist crockery by [[Arthur Boyd]] and [[John Perceval]],<ref>"Drawings, paintings and pottery by JOHN PERCEVAL are shown at Mirka's Cafe, 183 Exhibition St. The horrific and the playful share in the expressionism of this retrospective display. Color and paint are used freely, the painter's feelings determining what he sets down and how." {{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71693511 |title=Woman honored in art exhibition. |newspaper=[[The Argus (Melbourne)|The Argus]] |location=Melbourne |date=6 September 1955 |accessdate=23 November 2014 |page=9 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> were seated on surrealist furniture, and surrounded by murals and sculptures by [[Clifford Last]], Ian Sime and [[Julius Kane]]. In 1956, Georges Mora was elected President of the [[Contemporary Art Society (Australia)|Contemporary Art Society]]. Artists donated paintings towards an inaugural fundraising exhibition in 1957. In 1958 he established Café Balzac in [[East Melbourne, Victoria|East Melbourne]] gaining a reputation as a restaurateur serving classic French cuisine to an eager clientele,<ref>Stephen Downes (2003). ''Advanced Australian Fare: How Australian Cooking Became the World's Best''. Allen & Unwin. p.28-32</ref> which included a gathering of the most significant contemporary Australian artists, to whom he proffered the walls of his establishment.<ref>"The Café Balzac mural is the largest and one of the best known 'survivors' of the Australian Pop Movement of the early 1960's. The work was commissioned in 1962 by Georges Mora, the proprietor of the Café Balzac, East Melbourne. The mural was painted as individual panels by three Sydney based 'Annandale Imitation Realists': Colin "Countdown" Lanceley, Mike "Pancho" Brown and Ross "Pride of Day" Crothall in exchange for meals and accommodation. In the 1960's, The Café Balzac was a key artist meeting and eating place in Melbourne, and Ross Crothall's panel has an inscription "To George(sic) Mora, with love." Anne Carter, 'Cleaning The Café Balzac mural' pp.13-14 in ''Insights and Intuition: Abstracts of contributions to the 10th AICCM Paintings Group Symposium 4–5 May 2006 Brisbane'' edited by Gillian Osmond. (2006) Canberra: The Australian Institute for the Conservation of Cultural Materials (AICCM) Inc. Paintings Special Interest Group</ref> Georges and Mirka relocated their business, opening in 1965 the Tolarno Restaurant and Galleries<ref>The Mora's artistic influence on Melbourne has been recognised with the Heritage Council adding St Kilda's Tolarno Hotel to the Victorian Heritage Register.{{Citation | title=Tolarno heritage status. | journal=The Age|location=Melbourne| publication-date=2009-05-22 | pages=3 | issn=0312-6307 }}</ref> in Melbourne's bohemian [[St Kilda, Victoria|St Kilda]]. The rear of the building became a venue for exhibitions of [[avant-garde]] art and was soon surrounded by other galleries.
== Aspendale ==
The Moras' modernist house at bayside [[Aspendale, Victoria|Aspendale]] was regularly visited by artists [[Charles Blackman]], [[Albert Tucker (artist)|Albert Tucker]], [[John Perceval]], [[Sidney Nolan]], [[Joy Hester]], [[John Olsen]], [[Colin Lanceley]], [[Gareth Sansom]], [[Mike Brown (artist)|Mike Brown]], [[Martin Sharp]], [[Asher Bilu]] and [[Ivan Durrant]].<ref>{{Citation | author1=Mora, Mirka | author2=[[Barbara Blackman|Blackman, Barbara]], 1928- (Interviewer) | title=Mirka Mora interviewed by Barbara Blackman | publication-date=1984 | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/22475297 | accessdate=23 November 2014 }}</ref> They were joined by prominent journalists and writers Barrett Reid, Brian McArdle and Philip Jones,<ref>Philip Jones (2005). ''Art & Life''. Allen & Unwin. (NOTE: Philip Jones is the former assistant director of the Museum of Modern Art in Tavistock Place, Melbourne, which is now the MOMA at Heide.)</ref> who found company amongst the likes of French [[mime]] [[Marcel Marceau]],<ref>"MIRKA Mora first met Marcel Marceau when she joined his mime classes at a Paris theatre school in 1946." {{Citation | title=Painter's truth in a mime of knowledge.(Features)(Column) | journal=The Australian | publication-date=2003-11-13 | pages=012 | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/69784100 | accessdate=23 November 2014 }}</ref> [[Barry Humphries]], photographers such as [[Robert Whitaker (photographer)|Robert Whitaker]]<ref>{{Citation | title=Snapper to pop stars and artists learnt skills in war. | journal=The Age | location=Melbourne | publication-date=2011-10-03 | pages=18 | issn=0312-6307 }}</ref> and [[Mark Strizic]], and filmmaker [[Nigel Buesst]]. Built by architect Peter Burns, the house<ref>see catalogue of Mornington Peninsula Regional Gallery [http://mprg.mornpen.vic.gov.au] exhibition curated by Rodney James ''Aspendale Beach: an artists' haven'' 12 December 2007 – 10 March 2008</ref> opened onto a common courtyard<ref>{{Citation | author1=Perkin, Corrie | title=Bohemia by the sea [The beach houses of Georges and Mirka Mora and Sunday and John Reed in Aspendale, Melbourne, were a magnet for Australia's most famous artists] | journal=Weekend Australian Magazine | publication-date= 2007-12-09| issue=8-9 Dec 2007 | pages=46–49 | issn=1038-8761 }}</ref> shared by the Moras' close friends [[Sunday Reed|Sunday]] and [[John Reed (art patron)|John Reed]] art patrons and founders of the [[Heide Circle]].<ref>Janine Burke (2004). ''The heart garden: Sunday Reed and Heide''. Knopf. see Pages 321, 348, 435.</ref>
Sons [[William Mora]], born in 1953, and [[Tiriel Mora]] (1958), are respectively an art dealer and an actor.
== Tolarno Galleries == In 1969, to avoid bankruptcy, Mora sold the Tolarno hotel and leased out the restaurant and gallery. In the early 1970s he separated from Mirka. In 1979, Georges sold the restaurant to Leon Massoni and relocated the Tolarno Galleries to River Street, [[South Yarra, Victoria|South Yarra]].<ref>July 14, 1982, Ivan Durrant, [[Asher Bilu]] and [[Luba Bilu]] made an agreement with Leon Massoni, the new owner of Tolarno restaurant, to take over the old Tolarno Gallery, with [[Ivan Durrant]] to create United Artists Gallery, as an artist-run co-operative (1982 to 1985) which included Mike Brown, Dale Hickey, Don Laycock and Peter D. Cole amongst others</ref> The opening show there included [[lithographs]] by [[Pierre-Auguste Renoir|Renoir]] secured through his work as a dealer for [[Daniel Wildenstein]]. Georges travelled to the USA and Europe<ref>John Reed, Barrett Reid and Nancy Underhill, Barrett Reid (Editors) (2001). ''Letters of John Reed: defining Australian cultural life 1920-1981''. Viking. Pages 17, 495, 791</ref> promoting the international reputation of Australian art, and selling European, American and Australian art into his adopted country's national, state, regional and corporate collections,<ref>''The art of the collection'', Issue 94 of Miegunyah Press series (2007). State Library of Victoria, Miegunyah Press. Pages 128-30</ref> lending work for a very significant [[Pierre Bonnard|Bonnard]] exhibition touring Melbourne, Sydney, Adelaide and Perth state museums in 1971.<ref>National Gallery of Victoria (1971). Pierre Bonnard, 1867-1947. Melbourne: National Gallery of Victoria</ref> Exhibitions in the first years (1967–69) of the new gallery also presented radical hard-edge abstractions by [[Dale Hickey]] and [[Robert Hunter (artist)|Robert Hunter]] and sculpture by Ti Parks. [[William Mora]] joined his father in running the gallery before setting up his own in the city. Jan Minchin, who came from a position at the [[National Gallery of Victoria]], was Georges co-director from 1989. Throughout its career, Tolarno Galleries supported challenging contemporary art,<ref>Bernard Smith, Terry E. Smith and Christopher Robin Heathcote (Editor) ''Australian painting, 1788-2000'', 4th ed. Oxford University Press, 2001. Page 395</ref> including eight shows of highly-charged politico-sexual imagery by [[Juan Davila(artist)|Juan Davila]].<ref>National Library of Australia. Juan Davila (1971–1994) Manuscript Book and Archival Material. OCLC Number: 225809387. Manuscript reference no.: NLA MS 9578.</ref>
In 1985 Georges married artist Caroline Williams when their son, Sam, was born. Georges was made a [[Chevalier des Arts et des Lettres]] by the French government in 1989 and he was a strong supporter of the move toward multiculturalism in his adopted country.
== Death == On June 7, 1992, at the age of 78, and still energetically running the Tolarno Gallery, Mora died of a brain tumour. He was buried at [[Cheltenham, Victoria|Cheltenham]] New Cemetery, where his grave bears the quip 'Out to Lunch'.
Tolarno continues under the directorship of Jan Minchin in new premises at Level 4, 104 Exhibition Street, Melbourne.<ref>not far from the site of ''Mirka Café'' of the 1950s</ref> George and Mirka's son William Mora continues the family tradition as the director of William Mora Galleries at 60 Tanner St.Richmond.
== The Georges Mora Foundation == In Georges' memory [http://www.georgesmorafoundation.org.au/ ''The Georges Mora Foundation''] was established in 2006. It is a not-for-profit cultural foundation dedicated to the promotion of contemporary art and artists in Melbourne and Australia. In May 2006, the foundation was officially launched by Baillieu Myer with inaugural Patron, Dame Elisabeth Murdoch. The foundation awards a fellowship each year to a contemporary artist whose work conveys a sense of [[gravitas]]. Georges Mora Foundation Fellowships have been awarded to Jude Walton, Catherine Evans, Inez de Vega, Brook Andrew & Trent Walter, Linda Tegg, Ross Coulter, Philip Brophy, Cyrus Tang & Trinh Vu.

{{nihongo|'''Gocco'''|プリントゴッコ|Purinto Gokko|"Print Gocco"}} is a self-contained compact color printing system invented in 1977 by Noboru Hayama. Gocco became immensely popular in Japan and it is estimated that one-third of Japanese households own a Print Gocco system.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Bliss | first = Jill | title = Long Live Gocco | journal = CRAFT | volume = 1 | issue = 1 | pages = 50 | publisher = O'Reilly | year = 2006 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=F-DcK0QY3ZwC | isbn = 978-0-596-52928-4 | accessdate = 2008-05-28 }}</ref> The printing mechanism is that of [[screen printing]]. The Gocco sets included the materials and tools to both make the screens, and to use these screens for printing. As the Gocco screens are quite small, they were most widely used for printing [[greeting card]]s, a popular need within Japanese culture. Gocco could also print to fabrics, although only across a small area. The Gocco printing screens did offer good [[printing registration|registration]], so two or more colour printing was practical and popular.
The name "print gocco" is derived from the [[Japanese language|Japanese]] word {{nihongo|''gokko''|[[:ja:ごっこ遊び|ごっこ]]}}, loosely translated as make-believe play. Riso Kagaku president Noboru Hayama explained, "We [as kids] learned rules and knowledge through make-believe play. The spirit of play is an important cultural asset. I thought that I wanted to leave "play" in the product's name."
== Printing method == The Gocco process was scaled down, but otherwise very similar to large commercial screen printing techniques. The equipment included simple plastic holders for screen making and printing.
[[Screen printing]] uses a mesh screen that is coated with an impermeable paint-like material to make a stencil of the design. The ink can pass through the bare mesh, but is stopped by the impermeable stencil material. These screens are made by the printer before use, either by painting the stencil material only where it is needed or more commonly, as with the Gocco, by a simple photographic process.
=== Screen making === Artwork was prepared as a simple black and white illustration on paper. This could be done by hand, with ink, paint or pencil, or by computer printing (although the original Gocco pre-dated home computer printing). A translucent lightweight paper and a solidly opaque illustration gave better results and sharper prints. It was also possible to use [[photogram]]s, using a natural material such as a [[leaf]] as an artwork of found-materials.
The raw screen was first coated overall with a stencil material. This was then sandwiched with the artwork and the Gocco's simple battery-powered lightbox was used to expose the screen. This used [[Flash (photography)|flash bulbs]] similar to those found in old cameras. The exposed screen could then be developed to wash away the unexposed areas (i.e. those shielded by the artwork), producing a stencil screen.
Where multiple colours were to be printed, a separate screen was made for each colour.
Gocco screens could be used repeatedly. The original patent cites a potential lifetime of 2000 prints, although few Gocco users were interested in such volumes. If cleaned of ink after printing, a screen could also be stored for future printing.
Used screens could be washed clean of the stencil afterwards, re-coated and re-used with new designs.
=== Printing === Printing was as for conventional screen printing. The screen and the paper to be printed were sandwiched in the Gocco printing frame. A [[squeegee]] was then used to work a viscous ink around the screen, passing through the mesh in the bare parts of the stencil and onto the paper.
== Decline == In December 2005, Gocco’s parent company, [[Riso Kagaku Corporation]], announced it would end production of the Gocco system due to low sales in Japan. An Internet campaign was started to find a new home for the product.
As of June 2007, Riso Kagaku Corporation had resumed production of several lines of Print Gocco units and they were available in Japan and through limited import retail stores in the United States.<ref>{{cite web | title = News of October 24, 2007 | publisher = Save Gocco | date = 2007-10-24 | url = http://savegocco.com/news.html | accessdate = 2015-04-23 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080314184844/http://www.savegocco.com/news.html | archivedate = 2008-03-14 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Do you Gocco? You will. | first = Tina | last = Henry | publisher = Washington City Paper | date = 2007-06-20 | url = http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/blogs/craftybastards/2007/06/20/do-you-gocco-you-will/ | accessdate = 2008-05-28 }}</ref>
On May 30, 2008, the [[Riso Kagaku Corporation]] announced that it would stop shipping Gocco printers in June 2008. It blamed the sharp decline in demand for its printers on the increase in use of home computers and printers. It was to continue producing supplies for the printers.<ref>{{cite web | title = Riso Kagaku to Pull Plug on 'Print Gocco' Home Printer | work = Jiji Press | publisher = JCN Network | url = http://www.japancorp.net/Article.Asp?Art_ID=18414 | date = 2008-05-30 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090804054456/http://www.japancorp.net/Article.Asp?Art_ID=18414 | archivedate = 2009-08-04 | accessdate = 2015-04-23 }}</ref>

The '''Guggenheim UBS MAP Global Art Initiative''' is a five-year program, supported by Swiss bank [[UBS]] in which the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation]] identifies and works with artists, curators and educators from [[South Asia|South]] and [[Southeast Asia]], [[Latin America]], and the [[Middle East]] and [[North Africa]] to expand its reach in the international art world. For each of the three phases of the project, the museum invites one curator from the chosen region to the [[Solomon R Guggenheim Museum]] in [[New York City]] for a two-year curatorial residency, where he or she works with a team of Guggenheim staff to identify new artworks that reflect the range of talents in their parts of the world. The resident curators organize international touring exhibitions that highlight these artworks and help organize educational activities.<ref name=vogel3>Vogel, Carol. [https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/12/arts/design/guggenheim-and-ubs-project-plan-cross-cultural-program.html "Guggenheim Project Challenges 'Western-Centric View'"], ''The New York Times'', April 11, 2012</ref><ref>"[https://www.guggenheim.org/map/map-curatorial-statement Guggenheim UBS MAP Global Art Initiative: MAP Curatorial Statement]." Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation. 12 April 2012. Retrieved 8 May 2012.</ref> The Foundation acquires these artworks for its permanent collection and includes them as the focus of exhibitions that open at the museum in New York and subsequently travel to two other cultural institutions or other venues around the world. The Foundation supplements the exhibitions with a series of public and online programs, and supports cross-cultural exchange and collaboration between staff members of the institutions hosting the exhibitions.<ref>Zhang, Kathy. [http://artasiapacific.com/News/GuggenheimUBSMAPGlobalArtInitiative "Guggenheim UBS MAP Global Art Initiative"], ''[[ArtAsiaPacific]]'' magazine, April 24, 2012</ref><ref>"[https://www.guggenheim.org/map Guggenheim UBS MAP Global Art Initiative]." Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation. Retrieved 16 August 2012.</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Yang|first1=Christina|title=An Educator's Reflections on Global Museum Work|url=http://blogs.guggenheim.org/map/educators-reflections-global-museum-work/|website=blogs.guggenheim.org|publisher=Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum|accessdate=17 July 2014}}</ref> UBS is reportedly contributing more than $40 million to the project to pay for its activities and the art acquisitions.<ref>Russeth, Andrew. [http://galleristny.com/2012/04/guggenheim-ubs-unite-for-global-art-initiative-focused-on-emerging-markets/ "Guggenheim, UBS Unite for Global Art Initiative Focused on 'Emerging Markets'"], GalleristNY.com, ''New York Observer'', April 2012</ref> Foundation director [[Richard Armstrong (museum director)|Richard Armstrong]] commented: "We are hoping to challenge our Western-centric view of art history."<ref name=vogel3/>
==Phase 1: South and Southeast Asia== The first exhibition, ''No Country: Contemporary Art for South and Southeast Asia'' is curated by [[June Yap]].<ref name=Cotter>{{cite news| last=Cotter|first=Holland|title=Acquired Tastes of Asian Art ‘No Country,’ New Asian Art at the Guggenheim|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/22/arts/design/no-country-new-asian-art-at-the-guggenheim.html?_r=0|accessdate=6 March 2014|newspaper=The New York Times|date=21 February 2013}}</ref> Yap has worked for six years in the curatorial departments of modern and contemporary art museums, including the [[Institute of Contemporary Arts Singapore]] and the [[Singapore Art Museum]].<ref>Chayka, Kyle. [http://www.blouinartinfo.com/museums/article/799029-map-quest-singaporean-curator-june-yap-on-the-guggenheims-intrepid-new-non-western-art-initiative "MAP Quest: Singaporean Curator June Yap on the Guggenheim's Intrepid New UBS-Backed Non-Western Art Initiative"], BLOUINARTINFO.com, April 12, 2012</ref> She gathered art from Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Myanmar, Vietnam, Cambodia, the Philippines, Bangladesh and India for ''No Country''. The exhibition was shown at the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]] in New York in 2013,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.guggenheim.org/map/south-and-southeast-asia|title=Guggenheim UBS MAP Global Art Initiative: South and Southeast Asia.|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation|access-date=|accessdate=17 July 2014}}</ref> the [[Asia Society#Global centers|Asia Society Hong Kong Centre]] from October 2013 to February 2014,<ref>{{cite web|title=No Country: Contemporary Art for South and Southeast Asia|url=http://asiasociety.org/hong-kong/exhibitions/no-country-contemporary-art-south-and-southeast-asia|website=asiasociety.org|publisher=Asia Society|accessdate=17 July 2014}}</ref> and [[Singapore| Singapore's]] Centre for Contemporary Art from May to July 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=No Country: Contemporary Art for South and Southeast Asia|url=http://ntu.ccasingapore.org/exhibitions/no-country-contemporary-art-for-south-and-southeast-asia/|website=NTU Centre for Contemporary Arts Singapore|accessdate=8 April 2016}}</ref>
In this show, the artists featured are as follows:<ref>"[https://www.guggenheim.org/map/south-and-southeast-asia Guggenheim UBS MAP Global Art Initiative: South and Southeast Asia, Artists]." Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation. Retrieved 4 April 2014.</ref>
{{div col|colwidth=20em}} * [[Bani Abidi]] * Reza Afisina * Khadim Ali * [[Poklong Anading]] * [[Aung Myint]] * Simryn Gill * [[Sheela Gowda]] * [[Shilpa Gupta]] * Ho Tzu Nyen * [[Amar Kanwar]] * Kamin Lertchaiprasert * Vincent Leong * [[Tayeba Begum Lipi]] * [[The Propeller Group|Tuan Andrew Nguyen]] * The Otolith Group * [[Sopheap Pich]] * [[The Propeller Group]] * Araya Rasdjarmrearnsook * [[Navin Rawanchaikul]] * Norberto Roldan * Arin Dwihartanto Sunaryo * [[Tang Da Wu]] * Tran Luong * [[Trương Tân|Truong Tan]] * [[Vandy Rattana]] * Wah Nu and Tun Win Aung * Wong Hoy Cheong {{div col end}}
==Phase 2: Latin America== The second exhibition of the project, ''Under the Same Sun: Art from Latin America Today'', focuses on art from Latin America<ref>"[https://www.guggenheim.org/map/latin-america Guggenheim UBS MAP Global Art Initiative: Latin America]." Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation. Retrieved 16 July 2014.</ref> and is curated by [[Pablo León de la Barra]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Russeth|first=Andrew|title=Guggenheim’s UBS Map Global Art Initiative Taps Pablo León de la Barra as Curator for Latin America|url=http://galleristny.com/2013/08/guggenheims-ubs-map-global-art-initiative-taps-pablo-leon-de-la-barra-as-curator-for-latin-america/|accessdate=6 March 2014| newspaper= Gallerist|date=1 August 2013}}</ref> On display are works by 40 artists representing 15 countries in Latin America, including Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Guatemala, Honduras, Mexico, Panama, Peru, Uruguay and Venezuela.<ref>{{cite news|last=Pollack| first=Maika| title= ‘Under the Same Sun: Art From Latin America Today’ at the Guggenheim|url=http://galleristny.com/2014/06/under-the-same-sun-art-from-latin-america-today-at-the-guggenheim/|accessdate=16 July 2014| newspaper= Gallerist| date=18 June 2014}}</ref> The artworks are organized around five themes: [[Conceptualism]] and its Legacies, Tropicologies, Political Activism, [[Modernism]] and its Failures, and Participation/Emancipation.<ref>{{cite news|title=‘Under the Same Sun: Art From Latin America Today’ opens at the Guggenheim| url=http://artdaily.com/news/70754/-Under-the-Same-Sun--Art-from-Latin-America-Today--opens-at-the-Guggenheim-Museum#.U8bVX5RdVAI|accessdate=16 July 2014|newspaper=Art Daily|date=18 June 2014}}</ref> The show ran at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York from June 13 to October 1, 2014, at [[Colección Júmex#Museo J.C3.BAmex|Museo Jumex]] in [[Mexico City]] from November 19, 2015 to February 7, 2016,<ref>{{cite news|last=Pollack| first=Maika|title=‘Under the Same Sun: Art From Latin America Today’ at the Guggenheim| url=http://galleristny.com/2014/06/under-the-same-sun-art-from-latin-america-today-at-the-guggenheim/|accessdate=16 July 2014|newspaper=Gallerist|date=13 June 2014}}</ref> and recently opened at the [[South London Gallery]] in [[Camberwell|Camberwell, London]] on June 10, 2016 and will be on view until September 4, 2016.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.laht.com/article.asp?ArticleId=2413942&CategoryId=13003|title="Under the Same Sun" Brings Vibrant Colors of Latin America to London|last=|first=|date=9 June 2016|work=|access-date=9 June 2016|via=Latin American Herald Tribune}}</ref>
In this show, the artists featured are as follows:<ref>"[https://www.guggenheim.org/map/latin-america Guggenheim UBS MAP Global Art Initiative: Latin America: Artists]." Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation. Retrieved 16 July 2014.</ref>
{{div col|colwidth=20em}} * [[Allora & Calzadilla|Jennifer Allora and Guillermo Calzadilla]] * [[Carlos Amorales]] * [[Armando Andrade Tudela]] * Alexander Apóstol * [[Tania Bruguera]] * Paulo Bruscky * [[Luis Camnitzer]] * [[Mariana Castillo Deball]] * Alejandro Cesarco * Raimond Chaves and Gilda Mantilla * Donna Conlon and Jonathan Harker * Adriano Costa * [[Minerva Cuevas]] * Jonathas de Andrade * Wilson Díaz * [[Juan Downey]] * [[Rafael Ferrer (artist)|Rafael Ferrer]] * [[Regina José Galindo]] * Mario García Torres * [[Dominique Gonzalez-Foerster|Dominique González-Foerster]] * Tamar Guimarães * Federico Herrero * [[Alfredo Jaar]] * Claudia Joskowicz * Runo Lagomarsino * [[David Lamelas]] * [[Marta Minujín]] * Carlos Motta * [[Iván Navarro (artist)|Iván Navarro]] * [[Rivane Neuenschwander]] * [[Gabriel Orozco]] * Damián Ortega * [[Amalia Pica]] * [[Wilfredo Prieto]] * [[Paul Ramirez Jonas|Paul Ramírez Jonas]] * [[Beatriz Santiago Muñoz]] * Gabriel Sierra * Javier Téllez * Erika Verzutti * Carla Zaccagnini {{div col end}}
In conjunction with ''Under the Same Sun'', [[Alfredo Jaar]]'s ''A Logo for America'' (1987), an animation for an electronic billboard in [[Times Square]], was shown again in Times Square in August 2014 as part of Times Square Alliance's "Midnight Moments" series.<ref>Martinez, Alana. [http://blogs.artinfo.com/artintheair/2014/05/29/heres-all-the-public-art-happening-this-summer-in-times-square/ "Here’s All the Public Art Happening This Summer in Times Square"], Blouin Artfino, May 29, 2014</ref>
Artist Federico Herrero, whose work is displayed in ''Under the Same Sun'', completed a residency at the South London Gallery from May to June 2016, during which he engaged with the local residents of Pelican Estate, Peckham and created a site-specific work in the children's playground of the community.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/goingout/colourful-playground-mural-brings-art-to-social-estate-in-peckham-as-part-of-south-london-gallery-s-a3268366.html|title=Colourful playground mural brings art to social estate in Peckham as part of South London Gallery’s newest exhibition|last=Portocarrero|first=Marta|date=11 June 2016|work=|access-date=18 July 2016|via=}}</ref>
==Phase 3: Middle East and Northern Africa== The UBS MAP Global Art Initiative culminates in a third and final exhibition titled, ''But a Storm is Blowing from Paradise: Contemporary Art of the Middle East and North Africa,''<ref name="Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation">{{Cite web|url=https://www.guggenheim.org/press-release/85063|title=Guggenheim Presents Recent Art from the Middle East and North Africa in the Third Exhibition of the Guggenheim UBS MAP Global Art Initiative|last=|first=|date=28 April 2016|website=|publisher=Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation|access-date=}}</ref> curated by [[Sara Raza]].<ref name=Seaman>{{cite news| last=Seaman|first=Anna|title=Sara Raza’s Guggenheim post turns the focus on regional art|url=http://www.thenational.ae/arts-lifestyle/art/sara-razas-guggenheim-post-turns-the-focus-on-regional-art|accessdate=10 April 2015|newspaper=The National|date=1 February 2015}}</ref> The show opened on April 29, 2016 at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York City and will be on view until October 5, 2016. The exhibition will travel to Istanbul's [[Pera Museum]] in 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.guggenheim.org/map/middle-east-and-north-africa|title=Guggenheim UBS MAP Global Art Initiative: Middle East and North Africa|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation|access-date=19 February 2016}}</ref>
In this show, the artists featured are as follows:<ref name="Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation"/>
{{div col|colwidth=20em}} * Kader Attia * [[Abbas Akhavan]] * Ergin Çavuşoğlu * [[Lida Abdul]] * [[Mariam Ghani]] * [[Rokni Haerizadeh]] * [[Susan Hefuna]] * [[Iman Issa]] * [[Nadia Kaabi-Linke]] * [[Mohammed Kazem]] * [[Ahmed Mater]] * [[Ala Younis]] * Zineb Sedira * [[Ori Gersht]] * [[Ali Cherri]] * [[Joana Hadjithomas]] and [[Khalil Joreige]] * [[Emily Jacir]] * [[Gülsün Karamustafa]] * Hassan Khan * [[Nadia Kaabi-Linke]]
{{div col end}}
''Hello Guggenheim: Film and Video Curated by Bidoun Projects'' was a four-week program of film and videos shown at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in May 2016 about the politics and power of the moving image, organized by [[Bidoun]] Projects.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.e-flux.com/announcements/public-programs-addressing-the-middle-east-and-north-africa/|title=But a Storm Is Blowing from Paradise: Contemporary Art of the Middle East and North Africa, Public programs|last=|first=|date=|website=E-flux|publisher=|access-date=18 July 2016}}</ref>
